State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China The epoxidation of long-chain α-olefins presents a significant challenge in synthetic chemistry, particularly when employing molecular oxygen from air as the sole oxidant under additive-free conditions. In this study, we demonstrate that manganese supported on mesoporous silica (Mn/MSN) effectively catalyzes the aerobic epoxidation of long-chain α-olefins without requiring initiators or sacrificial agents. Mechanistic investigations reveal a synergistic interplay between Mn(II) and Mn(III) species, which facilitates the selective cleavage the peroxo bonds (O–O) in alkyl hydroperoxide intermediates. Strategic incorporation of iron and zirconium into the Mn/MSN framework modulates the manganese oxidation states, enriching the Mn(II)/Mn(III) ratio and achieving a remarkable space-time yield of up to 200 mol epoxide mol⁻¹Mn h⁻¹ . Radical trapping experiments combined with high-resolution mass spectrometry corroborate the formation of allyl carbon-centered and alkoxy radical intermediates during the reaction. This work provides a feasible strategy for long-chain α-olefin aerobic epoxidation without any additives. Graphical Abstract Keywords Long-chain α-olefins Epoxidation Additives-free Air Radicals Mn/MSN Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the growing importance of long-chain α-olefins (LAOs) in the development of new materials, fine and bulk chemicals, novel production processes and catalysts for LAOs have emerged in recent years [1–3]. These advancements are expected to drive significant expansion in the industrial production capacity of LAOs. The conversion of LAOs to higher-carbon alcohols continues to be scientifically interesting and of practical value. In addition to hydroformylation/hydrogenation reactions for the production of primary alcohols from easily available olefins [4,5], the hydrogenation of epoxides establishes a novel linkage between LAOs and high-carbon alcohols [5,6]. Furthermore, 1,2-epoxides, from selective epoxidation of LAOs, are valuable building blocks for a variety of products ranging from polymers, surfactants to pharmaceutical applications ( Scheme 1 A) [5–10]. Undoubtedly, there is an increasing need for efficient and green epoxidation processes for LAOs in both academic and industrial circles. LAOs exhibit a lower HOMO energy, which tends to reduce their reactivity towards electrophilic oxidants [11]. Consequently, the transfer of oxygen atoms to CC becomes even more challenging [12]. Significant progress has been achieved in the epoxidation of LAOs catalyzed by a variety of non-heme iron and manganese complexes using aqueous H2O2 as terminal oxidant [13,14]. However, the use of a large number of organic solvents in the catalytic system and the difficulty in catalyst separation make these strategies not conducive to industrial production. The polyoxometalates have successfully addressed the catalyst separation and recycling problems, while having good epoxidation properties of LAOs also using H2O2 as the terminal oxidant (Table S1, Scheme 1B) [15]. In comparison, molecular oxygen (O2), especially in form of air, is the most desirable oxidant with respect to environmental and economic considerations. Nonetheless, O2 is relatively inert due to its triplet ground state [16]. This factor also causes low epoxy efficiency in LAOs [17]. In recent years, single - atom catalysts have been successfully applied in the epoxidation of styrene using O2 as the oxidant. Unfortunately, the applicability of these catalysts in the epoxidation of LAOs has not been addressed in the literature [18]. Generally, an excessive amount of aldehyde needs to be added to activate O2, but usually greater than fivefold the amount is required to ensure convert all the remaining substrate to generate aldehyde peroxy radicals (Scheme 1B) [19]. Recently, their research team have reduced the use of aldehydes to 1.5 equivalents and increased the selectivity of epoxides to more than 95 % by using the molecular sieve micropore confinement strategy [20]. Alternatively, employing a free radical initiator can trigger LAOs to generate allyl radicals (R•), thereby activating O2 to produce compounds with peroxy-alkyl radical (ROO•) (Scheme 1B) [21]. This can be seen as an autoxidation process. Otherwise, LAOs could be selectively epoxidized using air in conjunction with a peroxide initiator [22]. Hutchings and collaborators demonstrated that stabilizer-free internal linear alkenes can be effectively epoxidized with air using the carbon-supported gold catalyst. Unfortunately, LAOs still require the addition of an initiator to achieve reaction [23]. Kung and co-workers reported that Au nanoclusters can be used as free radical initiators for olefin autoxidation processes, but they did not verify whether this strategy was effective for epoxidation of LAOs [24]. It is well established that Co(II)- and Fe(II)-exchanged zeolites can activate O2 and catalyze epoxidation reactions when used alongside DMF. They highlighted that the choice of solvent is critical and proposed that the enhanced activity of the cobalt catalyst in DMF stems from the coordination of the solvent to Co(II), thereby forming the active site [25,26]. However, the applicability to the epoxidation of LAOs was also not investigated. Alkoxyl radicals (RO•) are regarded as key reactive oxygen species for epoxidation of LAOs [21,27]. Its production process usually takes a long time and might be the rate determining step [22,28]. For instance, Hutchings and co-workers used graphene oxide to catalyze the epoxidation of LAOs at 90°C, and the reaction was only partially productive after 20 h [17]. Even with the addition of a free radical initiator, it takes at least 10 h for a more significant product to be generated [21,22,28,29]. LAOs with allyl hydrogens can undergo allyl hydrogen extraction at elevated temperatures even in the absence of a catalyst. Subsequently, the formed R• interacting with O2 to form a ROO•. This process is well known in the autoxidation reactions of alkanes [30–32]. ROO• can propagate through H-transfer reactions to form new R• and hydroperoxide (ROOH), thereby accelerating the activation of reactants. On the other hand, ROO• can also bond with metals to form the complex such as M-O-O-R [32,33]. O-O bond in M-OOR complexes (eg. Cu(II)-OOR and Fe(Ⅲ)-OOR) have already been shown undergo both heterolytic or homolytic cleavage pathways [34–36]. Homolytic cleavage of the O-O bond is advantageous for generating RO• reactive oxygen species. Metal ion Lewis acidity have been claimed to promote O-O activation [37]. As for ROOH, it can also be homolytically decomposed by a redox active site [32]. Metals that bond with and those that promote O-O homolytic breaking exhibit different oxidation states. For example, Mn(II) participates in O-O breakage as a redox site, while Mn(III) can form a more stable complex with ROO• [31,32]. As result, the RO• generated by homolytic cleavage of O-O bonds can activate the reactants and also further participate in the epoxidation process of LAOs. Inevitably, ROO• and RO• recombine to form the corresponding alcohols and aldehydes, which results in lower yields of epoxy compounds [32]. Hutchings and co-workers have reported that the use of Au/graphene catalysts can suppresses the formation of allylic products and while enhancing the production of 1,2-epoxydecane through their involvement in activating the O-O bond [27]. Recently, electron-rich Co sites in a bimetallic Co-Ir composite were demonstrated to be more facile in activation of the O-O bond of the ROO• and then activate LAOs to generate epoxides [21]. From the above analysis, we conclude that appropriate metal sites are essential for generating reactive oxygen species necessary for LAOs epoxidation and for promoting reaction cycles. In this study, we elevated the reaction temperature to initiate the generation of radicals from LAOs. The generated R• react rapidly with O2 in air to form ROO•. To stabilize these intermediates, a Mn/MSN catalyst enriched in Mn(III) was then used to form a complex with the ROO•, preventing it from undergoing a recombination reaction. Subsequently, with the assistance of Mn(II) redox sites, a significant quantity of reactive RO• exhibiting epoxidation properties were produced. Concurrently, the free radical species present during the reaction facilitated the activation of LAOs, thus accelerating the epoxidation process (Scheme 1C). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of mesoporous SiO2 (MSNs) and MSNs-supported catalysts Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 20 g, Aladdin) and triethanolamine (TEA, 0.2 g, Energy Chemical) were homogenized in deionized water (180 mL, 80°C) using magnetic stirring for 0.5 h. Subsequently, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 15 mL, Energy Chemical) was added dropwise to the mixture. After a reaction period of 10 h, the suspension was centrifuged to collect the precipitate, which was then washed three times with water and ethanol, respectively. The resulting product was dried at 120°C for 10 h. Finally, the dried sample was heated to 600°C at a rate of 2 °C/min under static air conditions and maintained at this temperature for 3 h to obtain MSNs supports ( Scheme 2). The metal salts utilized in this study are nitrates. Notably, the precursor metal salts for Y and V consist of Y2O3 and V2O5, which were dissolved in nitric acid. The reagents employed in this step were procured from Macklin and used directly without any further treatment. The catalyst was prepared using the incipient-wetness impregnation method. Specifically, the water absorption capacity of MSNs was first measured to be 4 mL/g. Subsequently, a specific amount of metal salt was dissolved in 2 mL of water, to which 10 % (w/w) polyethylene glycol (Macklin) was added to facilitate the dispersion of the metal on MSNs. After sonication for 5 min, 200 µL of this solution was taken and combined with 50 mg of MSNs supports. The mixture was then dried at room temperature for 12 h. Following drying, the samples were heated to 600°C at a rate of 2 °C/min under static air conditions and maintained at that temperature for 2 h to obtain Metal/MSNs catalysts. DK-Al2O3 was obtained from Tianjin Keventer Technology Co., while Y molecular sieves, TS-1, and P25 were sourced from Macklin. Prior to use, all four materials underwent roasting at 600°C for a duration of 3 h. The catalyst was synthesized using the incipient-wetness impregnation method. The specific preparation steps were consistent with those employed for MSNs. 2.2 Characterizations The solid catalysts were characterized by nitrogen physisorption; powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), electron microscopy (SEM/TEM), temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction(H2-TPR), infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-band continuous wave (CW) EPR, high-resolution mass spectra (HRMS), extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and so on. See supporting information for details. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation In a typical reaction, 1-Decene (2 mL, Macklin ＞98 %), 10 mg of catalyst supported by MSN were mixed in a 15 mL glass bottle. The bottle was then placed in an autoclave and filled with 4 MPa air after three exchanges. Then immersed in a preheated metal bath (130°C) for 4 h at 600 rpm (under intrinsic kinetic conditions). After the reaction was completed, the products were extracted with ethyl acetate and analyzed by GC (FULI,9790Ⅱ) equipped with SH-5 column and FID detector, using n-hexadecane (Energy Chemical) as an internal standard. Product distribution determined by GC-MS (Shimadzu, QP2010). Using the internal standard method to calculate the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene. The 1,2-epoxydecene selectivity was estimated as the ratio of the target epoxide's peak area to the combined peak areas of all detected by-products due to the very complex products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of catalysts and reaction conditions We initiated our investigation into the aerobic epoxidation of 1-decene by examining the viability of the selective oxidation of LAOs with air in the absence of initiators and sacrificial agents under solvent-free conditions at 130 °C. Considering the effective contact between the reactants and the catalyst, we selected MSNs as the support. Based on the literature, MSNs were synthesized via a typical sol-gel approach involving the condensation of TEOS utilizing CTAB as a structure-directing agent and TEA as an alkaline catalyst [38]. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Figure S1) confirmed the mesoporous structure. Using the BET equation (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) and the BJH model (Barrett-Joiner-Halenda), we obtained MSNs with 565 m2/g surface area as well as 10.9 nm average pore diameter. (Table S2). Subsequently, the metals were loaded onto the MSNs via incipient wet impregnation (Scheme 2). After roasting, the samples were examined for their catalytic performance of selective epoxidation of 1-decene in a batch reactor. Figure S2 and Table 1 illustrate the catalytic activity of different metals supported on MSNs at 130°C. Transition metals supported on MSNs (theoretical loading, 0.24 mmol/g), especially Cr and Co, showed the highest catalytic activity, followed by Ce, Mo and Mn. When reaction temperature was reduced to 125°C, there was a decrease in yield for 1,2-epoxydecane, but Cr and Co still maintained considerable catalytic activity (Figure S3). For economic and environmental considerations, we selected Mn as the primary active metal and incorporated a secondary metal to modify its properties. Heterogeneous bimetallic catalysts have broad applications in industrial processes, serving as an effective approach to enhance catalytic performance [39]. The electronegativity difference induces charge transfer among Mn and second metal, which strongly affect the electronic structures and surface chemisorption characteristics. Initially, we set the loading of Mn at approximately 1.6 wt% (ICP results, Table S3), and then added about 0.24 mmol/g (MSNs) of selected main group elements and transition metal elements (theoretical loading, in particular Fe 0.3 mmol/g, Zr 0.13 mmol/g, as for Mn/MSN, an additional 0.24 mmol of Mn was added). At 130°C, the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene catalyzed by different second metals are shown in the Fig. 1a. It evident that different metals result in significant variations in catalytic performance. Compared to Mn/MSN catalyst, the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene over (Ti, Zr, Fe, Co, Cr-)Mn/MSN catalyst increased by two- to three-fold. Upon comparing Figure S2, it was observed that Co and Cr themselves have catalytic activity. Thus, Fe, Zr and Ti are really present as cocatalysts. When the reaction temperature was decreased by 5°C, ZrMn/MSN showed better low temperature reaction performance, which was about twice higher than that of Mn/MSN catalyst under the same conditions (Figure S4). Furthermore, experimental results revealed that the addition of the Group 1 (Na) and the Group 2 (Ca) will reduce the catalytic performance of Mn/MSN. The catalytic performance of Ni, Cu, Zn and other metals on Mn/MSN was not significantly improved. Similar reaction conditions (except for the reaction at 135°C) were employed for catalyzing epoxidation reactions involving both 1-tetradecene and 1-hexadecene with appreciable yields using ZrMn/MSN (Table 1). In order to gain a deeper understanding of the reaction process, we chose ZrMn /MSN and FeMn/MSN as catalysts for further research. The selectivity of 1,2-epoxydecene was about 30 %, regardless of the use of Fe or Zr catalysts. Similar results have also been reported in previous studies [17,21,29]. When the ZrMn/MSN catalyst was used, the conversion rate of 1-decene was approximately 19 %. We used GC-MS to analyze the products. It can be seen from Figure S5 that 1,2-epoxydecene is the main product, accompanied by 1-decen-3-one, n-caprylic acid, n-decanoic acid, 2-decenoic acid and 1,2-decanediol, which may be attributed to side reactions [21,27]. Then the reaction process was investigated by varying air pressure as well as the O2 content. The results at 130°C are presented in Figure S6; it can be seen that, by increasing the air pressure from 0.5 MPa to 4 MPa, the selectivity of 1,2-epoxydecene decreased from 39 % to 32 %. Notably, the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene was merely 0.09 mmol at 1 atm, suggesting that sufficient O2 dissolved in the reaction system is necessary. When using 1 atm of O2, however, 1,2-epoxydecene with a respectable yield of 0.65 mmol and 41 % selectivity, and 1,2-epoxydecene yielded up to 0.84 mmol at 0.5 MPa but with significantly lower selectivity. This indicates that excess O2 in the system will trigger more side reactions to take place. Afterwards, we examined the effect of catalyst dosage. As the quantity of catalyst increased from 5 mg to 25 mg, the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene rose while its corresponding selectivity remained relatively stable (Figure S7a). Moreover, with the decrease of Mn loading, the yield of product decreased slightly (Figure S7b), but the space-time yield (STY) increased significantly, up to 200 mol mol−1 Mn h−1, which represents nearly 12-fold higher than that of CoIr catalyst under the action of free radical initiator [21]. Next, the reaction performances with and without catalysts were evaluated under different temperatures and reaction times. The epoxidation of 1-decene can be conducted at elevated temperatures by an autoxidative process without using catalysts, although this necessitates a longer reaction time. e.g., only 0.11 mmol 1,2-epoxydecene was produced at 135°C for 5 h (Fig. 1b), whereas at the lower temperature of 120°C for 7 h, the yield was even less, at 0.04 mmol. When FeMn/MSN (Fe theoretical loading: 0.24 mmol/g MSNs) catalysts were used, comparable yields of 1,2-epoxydecene could be achieved while the reaction temperature was lowered by 15°C or the reaction time was shortened by more than 2 h. Similarly, ZrMn/MSN (Zr theoretical loading: 0.05 mmol/g MSNs) obtained equivalent yields of 1,2-epoxydecene at shorter times or lower temperatures than Mn/MSN (Figure S8). Furthermore, we determined the apparent activation energies for the reaction involving ZrMn/MSN, Mn/MSN, and the reaction without any catalyst, which were found to be ca. 91, 137, and 193 kJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 1c). These findings align closely with those reported by Xu [40]. Confirming that the addition of a catalyst decreases the activation energy of the epoxidation reaction, with ZrMn/MSN proving to be the most effective catalyst. We subsequently loaded FeMn or ZrMn onto different supports and investigated their catalytic performances, with the results presented in Figure S9. Among these supports, MSNs has the best performance. Despite Y zeolite having a higher specific surface area (Table S1), its performance is the worst. Compared with MSNs, the average pore size of Y zeolite was only 4.7 nm (Table S2). This may be a factor causing poor performance. The calculated size of 1-decene is 4.6 × 4.9 × 15.1 Å [20]. A larger pore is beneficial to the diffusion and mass transfer of 1-decene and the reaction intermediates. In addition, the catalytic properties of FeMn and ZrMn differed significantly when loaded on macroporous Al2O3 (DK-Al2O3) and titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1), whereas the performances were similar when loaded on MSNs (Figure S9). This suggests that the chemical properties of the supports also affect the interactions between the metals. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts The performance of catalysts produced by doping different metals into Mn/MSN is significantly different. Then, extensive investigations have been carried out to elucidate the relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic performances. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the support MSNs and FeMn/MSN sample are presented in Figure S1. BET surface area of the catalyst sample was measured at 487 m2/g, with a BJH average pore diameter of 12.9 nm (Table S2). Compared to the MSNs support, its specific surface area decreased, but an increase in average pore size was observed. This may be caused by the fact that some of the micropores are blocked after loading the metals. XRD characterization of the samples (scanning rate: 4°/min) revealed a peak around 2θ = 22°, which corresponds to the Si-O-Si peak associated with randomly arranged SiO2 tetrahedra within the amorphous structure of the MSNs pore wall [41] (Figure S10). While no X-ray diffraction peaks for crystalline MnOx phases were observed (Figure S10), the fact that the MnOx species were not detectable may suggest that they were amorphous or their particle sizes were below the detection limit of XRD [42]. The content of Mn in the particular catalyst was measured to be 1.5–1.6 % by ICP analysis (Table S3). SEM images of the samples are shown in Fig. 2 and Figure S11. the MSNs consists of aggregates composed of ∼20 nm uniform nanoparticles. Furthermore, the TEM images corroborate this finding. Concurrently, EDS analysis demonstrates that the metals were uniformly dispersed on the MSNs (Fig. 2, Figure S11). A variety of characterization techniques, including FTIR, Raman spectroscopy, XPS, TPD, EPR and EXAFS were employed to gain insights into the composition and structural features of the catalyst surfaces. The FTIR spectra for MSNs, Mn/MSN, FeMn/MSN, and ZrMn/MSN are presented in Figure S12, exhibiting three distinct absorption peaks at 1106, 812, and 500 cm−1, assigned to both asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the Si-O-Si bonds. A peak at 3745 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibrations of isolated silanol groups (Si-OH) in all samples. The characteristic peak of adsorbed H2O at 1631 cm⁻¹ was observed to decrease in Mn/MSN, FeMn/MSN, and ZrMn/MSN compared to MSNs, suggesting inhibited H2O adsorption after metal loading [43]. Raman spectra of MSNs, Mn/MSN and ZrMn/MSN were recorded using a 514.5 nm laser (Figure S13). There was no Raman band observed for amorphous MSNs [44], a MnOx Raman spectrum is generally characterized by two distinct marker modes in the ranges of 450–550 cm−1 and 550–750 cm−1 [45]. The peak at 608 cm−1 may correspond to a Mn-O-Si vibrational mode [46]. It should be noted here, laser-induced degradation cannot be completely excluded [47]. Nevertheless, it is still perceptible that the addition of Zr affects the Mn/MSN structure. O2-TPD experiments were used to investigate the interaction between the catalyst and O2, as well as to distinguish various oxygen species [48]. As illustrated in Fig. 3a, the O2-TPD profiles reveal that the catalysts presented different properties of oxygen species. Generally, the O2-TPD spectra can be separated into two regions, low temperature (<225°C) and high temperature (>225°C), which correspond to the release of surface oxygen molecules/active surface oxygen and lattice oxygen respectively [48]. The chemical bonds between Mn and O can be polarized, with the generation of electrophilic oxygen species [49]. Relative to the profiles in Mn/MSN, Zr/MSN and Fe/MSN (Figure S14), the onset desorption temperature of oxygen from ZrMn/MSN and FeMn/MSN occurred at a lower temperature and the desorbed oxygen amount, reflecting that the doping of Zr and Fe changed the polarization between the catalyst and O2, thereby enhancing the ability to adsorb O2. H2-TPR profiles were conducted to elucidate the redox properties of the catalysts (Fig. 3b). Two prominent H2 consumption peaks are observed at around 255 and 400°C. Compared to Mn/MSN, the Mn in FeMn/MSN and ZrMn/MSN exhibits significantly lower reducibility, indicating that there is a strong interaction between Fe or Zr and Mn. The peaks in different regions correspond to the reduction process of manganese in different oxidation states. In general, the peaks in the low temperature region reflect the reduction of MnOx with higher oxidation states (+3 - +4), while those in the high temperature region correspond to the reduction of MnOx with lower valence (+2 - +3). The intermediate transition manganese species are generally considered to be Mn3O4 or Mn2O3 [50,51]. According to the literature, with the increase of hydrogen consumption in the high temperature region, the average oxidation state of MnOx decreases [51]. Notably, Fe/MSN has a strong desorption peak around 315–400°C (Figure S15), which may have an effect on the H2 consumption of FeMn/MSN in the high temperature region. In contrast, the desorption peak of Zr/MSN in the high temperature region is not significant (Figure S15). This suggests that incorporating Fe or Zr promotes the stabilization of Mn species in lower oxidation states in the Mn/MSN system. XPS and Mn K-edge XANES spectra of the selected samples were collected to investigate the manganese oxide phases present in the catalysts. The Mn 2p spectrum of the samples exhibit a doublet Mn 2p3/2 - Mn 2p1/2 with binding energy signals at 642.2 and 654.2 eV respectively (Fig. 3c). In addition, a small satellite feature was observed, which indicates the existence of Mn(Ⅱ) alongside Mn(Ⅳ). The Mn2p2/3 peak of NiMn/MSN was observed to be shifted towards lower binding energies in comparison to that of Mn/MSN. It is worth noting that when the content of Ni is relatively high, the Mn 2p3/2 spectral peak is partially covered by the NiLMM Auger peak. Mn3s is considered to be effective in determining the valence state of complex manganese species [52]. Unfortunately, the low manganese content of our samples resulted in a weak intensity of the Mn3s peaks, which was not sufficient to provide an accurate analytical judgement. To address this limitation, we subsequently employed the Mn K-edge XANES spectra to further explore the oxidation state of Mn. As shown in Fig. 3d, the Mn K-edge energy for Mn/MSN were between Mn3O4 and MnO2, this is in line with the results reported by Oyama [53]. The energies changed with the addition of Zr, Na, and Ni, but remained between Mn3O4 and MnO2. Fig. 3e shows a unique feature called pre-edge that commonly occurs ∼ 10 eV before the edge. That is related to electronic transitions from the 1 s core levels to the empty 3d levels [54]. The addition of Zr, Na, and Ni to Mn/MSN induces a change in energy splitting and intensity distribution of the pre-edge feature, which are indicative of variations in spin state, oxidation state as well as geometry of Mn [55]. EPR spectroscopy has been employed to confirm the oxidation state and the chemical environment of the Mn species present in the samples. The X-band EPR spectrum of selected samples measured at room temperature is indicated in Fig. 3f. The MSN support itself was paramagnetic [56]. Since Mn(Ⅲ) (S = 2) is known as a “EPR-Silent” species when using traditional techniques [57], it can be inferred from Fig. 3f that the predominant form of manganese in Mn/MSN is Mn(Ⅲ). EPR reveals a distinct difference between the Mn/MSN and ZrMn/MSN materials, namely, a strong line broadening of the ZrMn/MSN was observed. The g-value of ZrMn/MSN was close to 2.09. As reported, Zr(Ⅲ) ions exhibit EPR signals at g = 1.98, while Mn(IV) shows signals at g ≈ 4 [58,59]. This suggests that the incorporation of Zr may increase the concentration of Mn(Ⅱ) species. We used Mn(NO3)2 for catalyst preparation. When the precursor was not roasted, Mn/MSN, FeMn/MSN, and ZrMn/MSN all exhibited peaks at g = 2.09, with ZrMn/MSN showing a significantly stronger peak (Figure S16). This may be related to the difference of electronegativity between Zr, Fe, and Mn ions [60]. Meanwhile, the nature of the MSN support also affects the interactions between the metals. From the corresponding reaction properties of the samples (Figure S17) [61], there exists a positive correlation between 1,2-epoxydecene production and Mn(Ⅱ) concentration. 3.3 Reaction mechanism insight from epoxidation rate measurements In situ diffusion reflectance Fourier transform infrared (in situ FT-IR) spectroscopy was applied to monitor the epoxidation reaction process. 1-Decene was carried by gas into the test system under ambient air atmosphere and at 130°C. As shown in Figure S18, the introduction of 1-decene to MSNs and FeMn/MSN resulted in the appearance of a series of IR bands at 3080,2926 and 2858 cm−1 assigned to C-H vibrations [62]. The characteristic absorption peak corresponding to the CC stretching vibration in terminal alkenes is typically observed within the spectral range of 1640–1680 cm−1 in infrared spectroscopy. Simultaneously, two distinct absorption bands associated with the out-of-plane bending vibrations of the vinylic C-H bonds are consistently detected at 990 cm−1 and 910 cm−1. Under ambient pressure in an air atmosphere at 130°C, distinct spectral discrepancies between FeMn/MSN and MSNs are observed at 1640–1680 cm−1, 995 cm−1 and 915 cm−1 (Figure S18). These characteristic vibrational features suggest the formation of interfacial interactions between FeMn species and 1-decene molecules under catalytic conditions. Additionally, we conducted diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis to investigate potential intermediate molecular structures adsorbed on both the MSNs support and FeMn/MSN catalyst surfaces at ambient temperature (Figure S19). The obtained spectra exhibited numerous complex characteristic absorption bands, precluding the unambiguous identification of potential reaction intermediates through in situ FT-IR. Furthermore, the low yield of 1,2-epoxydecene observed under atmospheric air conditions (Figure S6) significantly complicated the detection and characterization of transient intermediate species in this catalytic system. Kung and colleagues reported that Au nanoparticles supported on SiO2, which partially dissolve in the reaction system, form solubilized Au clusters with 7–8 atoms, these clusters can enhance the activation process of cyclohexene, generating a free radical initiator that facilitates the epoxidation reaction [24]. In order to verify in what form the catalyst acts during the catalytic reaction and how it catalyses the reaction, the following experiments were conducted. Firstly, reactions were carried out for several hours, and then hot filtration using a 0.22 μm syringe filter to remove all solids, succeeded by a further 4 h of reaction. The results of the reaction are shown in Fig. 4a. It was observed that when the reaction was filtered after 2 and 3 h and continued for another 4 h, there was a substantial increase in 1,2-epoxydecene yield, but it was still lower than when the reaction is carried out for 4 h without filtration. In contrast, when the reaction was filtered after 4 h and continued reaction with the addition of 1 mL of 1-decene, the yield was essentially unchanged. When the reaction was filtered after 2 and 3 h under N2 and then reacted for another 4 h, no product detected before or after filtration. This finding suggests that solubilized Mn clusters do not act as active species within this context. Additionally, we performed ICP tests on the filtrate after 4 h of reaction, in which the contents of Mn, Zr and Si were 24.3 ppb, 28.9 ppb and 2.5 ppm, respectively. As previously reported in the literature, aldehydes can be used as sacrificial agents in the epoxidation of LAOs, a process well known as Mukaiyama epoxidation [20]. The presence of aldehydes was detected in the filtrate for both 2 and 3 h of reaction under air, whereas it was not detected under N2. Mukaiyama epoxidation can occur either in the presence or absence of a metal catalyst. The addition of metal catalyst plays a role in the transfer of hydrogen atoms from the aldehyde or in the homolysis of the C-O/O-O of the peracid compounds produced from aldehyde. This in turn accelerates the reaction process [63,64]. In our study, we added 1 mmol of 1-octanal to the reaction system and compared the reaction performances between the addition of ZrMn/MSN and NaMn/MSN as well as without the addition of catalysts. Compared to without catalyst, the addition of ZrMn/MSN can significantly increase the reaction rate (Fig. 4b). Although NaMn/MSN exhibited slight acceleration during the initial phase; however, its activity diminished over time. 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) has been used as an initiator in the epoxidation reaction of LAOs [65]. Under our experimental conditions, with the addition of 0.5 mmol AIBN, the epoxide product was generated in 1 h of the reaction, which was 2 h shorter than the reaction time required without AIBN (Fig. 4c). The reaction rate then increased substantially from 1 to 1.5 h, after which the increase slowed down. This observation suggests that AIBN decomposed within approximately 1.5 h to produce a significant quantity of free radical species. With the simultaneous addition of AIBN and ZrMn/MSN, the reaction performance was similar in the first 1.5 h to that addition AIBN alone. After containing sufficient radical species, ZrMn/MSN marked improvement in the yield of 1,2-epoxydecene within the subsequent 1 h reaction time. R• generated by AIBN-initiated 1-decene rapidly react with O2 to generate ROO• [66,67]. Collectively, it can be concluded that ZrMn/MSN primarily serves to facilitate activation of ROO• during this process. Under the standard conditions for the epoxidation reaction, the addition of 1 mmol radical scavenger TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-yl-oxidanyl) completely suppressed the epoxidation process, suggesting that a radical intermediate is involved. Moreover, 1-decene radicals at the allylic position were obviously detected by high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) under a N2 atmosphere for 4 h (Fig. 4d). As shown in Figure S20, the intensity of the adduct peak is similar to that without the catalyst. In addition, the adduct was initially detected after 2 h with and without the addition of the catalyst, except that the intensity of the peak was slightly higher with the addition of the catalyst (Figure S21). This indicates that while the catalyst participates in free radical production processes, it does not significantly enhance carbon-centered radical production. Considering that the rate constant for the reaction between carbon-centered radicals and oxygen is close to the diffusion-controlled rate (109 M−1 s−1) [66,67], the radical from thermally initiated allyl hydrogen abstraction reacts rapidly with O2 as soon as it is produced. Under standard reaction conditions, HRMS detected the adduct of RO• with TEMPO (Figure S22a). We have also captured RO• species with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) under the standard reaction conditions (Figure S22b) [21]. No ROO• adducts were detected by HRMS, probably due to the decomposition of the adducts [68]. 3.4 Proposed LAOs epoxidation reaction mechanisms on Mn/MSN During the epoxidation reaction, the catalyst undergoes a gradual color change from tan to white. This indicates a high to low oxidation state of Mn [30]. The XPS test in Figure S23 illustrates the change in catalyst over time during the reaction, with the MnO satellite peaks becoming more intense and the width of the peaks broadening, which indicates an increase in Mn(II) content. Furthermore, the Mn K-edge XANES spectra of the spent ZrMn/MSN catalysts also show the absorption edge shifting to a lower energy (Fig. 4e,4f). These findings collectively indicate a decrease in the oxidation state of manganese in Mn-O bonds [69]. Next, we collected, washed, and dried the spent catalyst at 110°C. After adding it to the reaction system again, we found a significant decrease in activity (0.1 mmol yield). Evidently, Mn(III) and Mn(II) are important for the reaction of LAOs under conditions with no initiator or sacrificial agent. Building on the aforementioned observations and relevant literature, we determined that Mn-based catalysts are major involved in the of O-O bonds breaking process and then propose the following rationale for the LAOs epoxidation reaction mechanism in our catalytic system ( Scheme 3). The reaction is initiated by the formation of allyl carbon-centred radicals via the hydrogen-atom abstraction from an LAOs molecule at elevated temperatures (e.g., 1-decene at 130°C). This process usually takes a longer time. After 2 h of reaction, the initially produced R• reacts rapidly with O2 to produce ROO•. Because the increased electron deficiency of Mn(III) makes it a better acceptor of electrons supplied by ROO• [32]. Then ROO• is more likely to form complexes with Mn(III), thus reducing the recombination reactions. There are two alternative pathways for Mn(III)···ROO•, one is cleavage assisted by the redox sites Mn(II) to produce RO• with epoxidation reactivity [27]. Another pathway is the generation of ROOH, which can likewise generate RO• in the presence of Mn(II). According to the literature [32], Mn(II) generates Mn(III)OH after assisting in the breaking of the O-O bond of ROOH. Mn(III)OH can initiate ROOH to produce ROO• with simultaneous regeneration of Mn(II). Notably, the free radical species generated during the reaction can further trigger the activation of LAOs and accelerate the epoxidation process. It is worth mentioning that 2-decenoic acid was also detected by GC-MS, which is consistent with the findings reported by Hutchings [27]. This suggests that rapid allylic rearrangements occur between the two resonance structures (CH3CH=CHCH2•.and CH3CH•CH=CH2) [70]. Given that catalytic cycles based on these two structures exhibit similarities, we provide a schematic representation for one structure's cycle. Additionally, the interaction between the metal species in the Mn/MSN-based catalyst and the π-electron-rich CC bonds of 1-decene (as illustrated in Figure. S18) has been observed, which may further enhance the epoxidation reaction rate [71,72]. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully constructed synergistic sites with abundant Mn(II) and Mn(III) on the MSN by incorporating a second metal. This approach enhances the overall efficiency of the catalytic epoxidation reaction of LAOs, utilizing air as the oxidant without requiring a sacrificial agent or radical initiator. This catalyst exhibits a superior space-time yield of 200 mol mol−1 Mn h−1 in the production of 1,2-epoxydecane, which is approximately 12-fold higher than that achieved with CoIr. The systematic material characterizations, catalyst evaluations, and mechanistic studies indicate that efficient LAO epoxidation reactions necessitate the co-presence of both Mn(II) and Mn(III). The primary function of Mn(III) is likely stabilizes the ROO• species generated through thermal initiation, while Mn(II) is proposed to the cleavage of the O-O bond within these ROO• species, thereby producing RO• radicals that participate in the epoxidation process. The relative proportions of Mn(III) and Mn(II) can be modulated by adding a second metal. It was found that Fe and Zr enhance the Mn(II) content in the catalyst after roasting through their interaction with Mn. This strategy of generating free radicals by thermal initiation, with Mn involved in stabilizing and activating key reaction intermediates, can also be applied to LAOs with higher carbon numbers. coredata.dc:description: The epoxidation of long-chain α-olefins presents a significant challenge in synthetic chemistry, particularly when employing molecular oxygen from air as the sole oxidant under additive-free conditions. In this study, we demonstrate that manganese supported on mesoporous silica (Mn/MSN) effectively catalyzes the aerobic epoxidation of long-chain α-olefins without requiring initiators or sacrificial agents. Mechanistic investigations reveal a synergistic interplay between Mn(II) and Mn(III) species, which facilitates the selective cleavage the peroxo bonds (O–O) in alkyl hydroperoxide intermediates. Strategic incorporation of iron and zirconium into the Mn/MSN framework modulates the manganese oxidation states, enriching the Mn(II)/Mn(III) ratio and achieving a remarkable space-time yield of up to 200 mol epoxide mol⁻¹Mn h⁻¹ . Radical trapping experiments combined with high-resolution mass spectrometry corroborate the formation of allyl carbon-centered and alkoxy radical intermediates during the reaction. This work provides a feasible strategy for long-chain α-olefin aerobic epoxidation without any additives.
